Dear Phil,
 
Thank you for the clear case for logging assertions. This feature has been
"on the list" for at least eight of the ten years JUnit has been in
existence. The problem is that I have never found a way to add it without
breaking the architecture. For me, the additional ugliness has always
outweighed the additional utility. I'm open to suggestions, though.
 
Regards,
 
Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

  _____  

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Phil
Surette
Sent: Monday, June 09, 2008 4:24 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] A case for adding logging of assertions to junit



I'd like to make a case for adding logging of assertions into junit.
I've been using junit for many years, and something that I've found
both for myself and for people who I've mentored in XP practices is
that it is often helpful to get warm fuzzy feedback that your tests
are running and asserting what you think they are asserting. 

I notice that I'm not alone in this; I see there are several threads
where people were looking for this feature
(http://tech. <http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/17845>
groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/17845 "how to log
junit tests", http://tech.
<http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/18762>
groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/18762
"junit 4 & logging",
http://tech. <http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/12000>
groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/12000 "Log4J Logging
in JUnit")

Consider the following concocted unit test. It is not the purpose of
this test case to demonstrate good test case design ;)

1 public class MyTest extends junit.framework.TestCase{
2 List<Map>; mapList;
3 
4 protected void setUp() throws Exception {
5 //create some silly data
6 Map map1 = new HashMap();
7 map1.put("id", "vladimir");
8 Map map2 = new HashMap();
9 map2.put("id", "estragon");
10 Map map3 = new HashMap();
11 //might have to wait for a while for this one :)
12 map3.put("id", "godot");
13 mapList = new ArrayList();
14 mapList.add(map1);
15 mapList.add(map2);
16 mapList.add(map3);
17 }
18 
19 public void testMapIds(){
20 assertTrue("mapList has content", mapList.size() > 0);
21 for (Map map: mapList){
22 assertNotNull("map has id field", map.get("id"));
23 }
24 }
25 
26 public void testIdFormat(){
27 //at some point this will test that all ids are
lowercase...
28 }
29 
30 public void testIdLengths(){
31 assertTrue("mapList has content", mapList.size() > 0);
32 for (Map map: mapList){
33 String id = (String)map.get("id");
34 assertTrue("id "+id+" at least 8 characters long",
id.length() >=8);
35 }
36 }
37 }

What I would like to be able to do is to turn on some kind of
assertion logging that would allow me to see output such as the following:
(Note that this output was generated using my own tweaked
version of junit that uses log4j logging categories for
enabling/disabling both assertion logging and test summary logging):

INFO junit.echo.run.start - __BEGIN MyClassTest.testMapIds__
DEBUG junit.echo.assertTrue - (passed) mapList has content 
DEBUG junit.echo.assertNotNull - (passed) map has id field vladimir
DEBUG junit.echo.assertNotNull - (passed) map has id field estragon
DEBUG junit.echo.assertNotNull - (passed) map has id field godot
INFO junit.echo.run.summary - __SUMMARY MyClassTest.testMapIds__ (4
asserts)
INFO junit.echo.run.start - __BEGIN MyClassTest.testIdFormat__
WARN junit.echo.run.summary - __SUMMARY MyClassTest.testIdFormat__ <a
id="bogus"></a>(???no asserts???)
INFO junit.echo.run.start - __BEGIN MyClassTest.testIdLengths__
DEBUG junit.echo.assertTrue - (passed) mapList has content
DEBUG junit.echo.assertTrue - (passed) id vladimir at least 8
characters long
DEBUG junit.echo.assertTrue - (passed) id estragon at least 8
characters long
DEBUG junit.echo.assertTrue - (FAILED) id godot at least 8 characters long
WARN junit.echo.run.summary - __SUMMARY MyClassTest.testIdLengths__
(4 asserts) ASSERTION FAILED id godot at least 8 characters long

Being able to see output like this has a number of benefits such as

1) eliminating redundant logging statements - Many logging statements
in a JUnit test case simply output information that you've already
told JUnit about in your assertions. Developers often put these in as
a 'sanity check' to verify that the test is doing what they expected.
For example: because on lines such as line 22 I can see the toString
of the object that is not null, I get a warm fuzzy feeling that the
test is sane when I look at the logged results. I've noticed that when
developers write their tests they often add log statements or
System.outs to provide them this warm fuzzy feeling (often deleting
the same logging when the test is complete - and putting them back in
when debugging test failures)

2) improving assertion messages - it's often the case that the
first time you see the message for an assertion will be when the
assertion fails, which may not happen until you run a regression test
many moons after you coded the test. Unless you see the message
displayed when you are developing the test, you won't realize that the
message - if you provided one - is not be very helpful. Better
assertion messages also help to communicate to a developer what the
point of the assertion is both when it fails and when reading the test.

3) see finer-grain test results. Every assertion is a mini-test on its
own, but JUnit these mini-tests are invisible until they fail. 
Of course, most of the time that's the behaviour you want. But
when you're developing a test or debugging a test failure, it's
great to see what these smaller tests are doing.

4) by making logging easy, it can help to avoid the
using-system-outs-instead-of-asserts syndrome, where new junit test
writers will write "test cases" that actually just write a bunch of
stuff to the console that the test writer then eyeballs for expected
results

Notice that in the output above, there are also 'summary' lines which
show how many assertions were made in a particular test. These are
somewhat tangential to the main thread of this post, but it's nice to
be able to know how many assertions occur in a test case if only to
identify when a test case is written that never actually makes an
assertion - which is often a bad smell in a test case. It's also nice
when there is a test failure during a build run to see in a log the
start of the test case and the assertions that passed before the
failure occurred.

There are some problems with logging assertions that I have encountered:

1) if iterating over a collection and asserting each element, your log
can be overwhelmed. Maybe it would be useful to have some way of
hinting that a particular assertion should not create notifications;
maybe not.

2) the implementation I wrote creates a dependency on log4j (perhaps
this could be avoided by using a notification mechanism and shipping a
separate component that listens for logging notifications and logs them)

BTW, From my own experience in instrumenting junit 3.8.1 
(some time ago) I found that it is not a trivial thing to modify 
junit to do this kind of logging. For instance, in my
own implementation I managed to confuse junit so it no longer reports
junit failures differently than errors. It is a
significant effort to do this badly, and much more effort to do it
well ;).

Is there any appetite out there for adding assertion logging (or
assertion notification) into the junit 4 framework? I would be
happy to do the work if I thought it would be accepted into the
main junit distribution. Or maybe this capability already exists
in some way in junit 4 that I am not aware of?
